metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: SQL Aliases
SQL Aliases
SQL aliases are used to give a table, or a column in a table, a temporary name.
content.html: SQL aliases are used to give a table, or a column in a table, a temporary name.

content.text: Aliases are often used to make column names more readable.
content.html: Aliases are often used to make column names more readable.

content.text: An alias only exists for the duration of that query.
content.html: An alias only exists for the duration of that query.

content.text: An alias is created with the AS keyword.
content.html: An alias is created with the AS keyword.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT CustomerID AS ID
 FROM Customers;

content.code:
SELECT CustomerID AS ID
FROM Customers;

syntax_highlighting.text:
SELECT CustomerID AS ID
 FROM Customers;

content.code_html:
SELECT CustomerID AS ID
FROM Customers;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT CustomerID AS ID
 FROM Customers;

content.text: AS is Optional
Actually, in most database languages, you can skip the AS keyword and get the same result:
content.html: Actually, in most database languages, you can skip the AS keyword and get the same result:

content.code_html:
SELECT CustomerID ID
FROM Customers;

content.text: Syntax
When alias is used on column:
content.html: When alias is used on column:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT column_name AS alias_name
 FROM table_name;

content.code: SELECT column_name AS alias_name FROM table_name;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT column_name AS alias_name
 FROM table_name;

content.text: When alias is used on table:
content.html: When alias is used on table:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT column_name(s)
 FROM table_name AS alias_name;

content.code: SELECT column_name(s) FROM table_name AS alias_name;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT column_name(s)
 FROM table_name AS alias_name;

content.text: Demo Database
Below is a selection from the Customers and Orders tables used in the examples:
content.html: Below is a selection from the Customers and Orders tables used in the examples:

content.text: Customers

content.code_html:
CustomerID CustomerName ContactName Address City PostalCode Country
1

 Alfreds Futterkiste Maria Anders Obere Str. 57 Berlin 12209 Germany
2 Ana Trujillo Emparedados y helados Ana Trujillo Avda. de la Constitución 2222 México D.F. 05021 Mexico
3 Antonio Moreno Taquería Antonio Moreno Mataderos 2312 México D.F. 05023 Mexico

content.text: Orders
Alias for Columns
The following SQL statement creates two aliases, one for the CustomerID column and one for the CustomerName column:
content.html: The following SQL statement creates two aliases, one for the CustomerID column and one for the CustomerName column:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT CustomerID AS ID, CustomerName AS Customer
 FROM Customers;

content.code:
SELECT CustomerID AS ID, CustomerName AS Customer
FROM Customers;

syntax_highlighting.text:
SELECT CustomerID AS ID, CustomerName AS Customer
 FROM Customers;

content.code_html:
SELECT CustomerID AS ID, CustomerName AS Customer
FROM Customers;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT CustomerID AS ID, CustomerName AS Customer
 FROM Customers;

content.text: Using Aliases With a Space Character
If you want your alias to contain one or more spaces, like " My Great Products ", surround your alias with square brackets or double quotes.
content.html: If you want your alias to contain one or more spaces, like "My Great Products", surround your alias with square brackets or double quotes.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT ProductName AS [My Great Products]
 FROM Products;

content.code:
SELECT ProductName AS [My Great Products]
FROM Products;

syntax_highlighting.text:
SELECT ProductName AS [My Great Products]
 FROM Products;

content.code_html:
SELECT ProductName AS [My Great Products]
FROM Products;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT ProductName AS [My Great Products]
 FROM Products;

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT ProductName AS "My Great Products"
 FROM Products;

content.code:
SELECT ProductName AS "My Great Products"
FROM Products;

syntax_highlighting.text:
SELECT ProductName AS "My Great Products"
 FROM Products;

content.code_html:
SELECT ProductName AS "My Great Products"
FROM Products;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT ProductName AS "My Great Products"
 FROM Products;

content.text: Note: Some database systems allows both [] and "", and some only allows one of them.
content.html: Note: Some database systems allows both [] and "", and some only allows one of them.

content.text: Concatenate Columns
The following SQL statement creates an alias named "Address" that combine four columns (Address, PostalCode, City and Country):
content.html: The following SQL statement creates an alias named "Address" that combine four columns (Address, PostalCode, City and Country):

content.code_html:
SELECT CustomerName, Address + ', ' + PostalCode + ' ' + City + ', ' + Country AS Address
FROM Customers;

content.text: Note: To get the SQL statement above to work in MySQL use the following:
content.html: Note: To get the SQL statement above to work in MySQL use the following:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT CustomerName, CONCAT(Address,', ',PostalCode,', ',City,', ',Country) AS Address
FROM Customers;

content.code:
SELECT CustomerName, CONCAT(Address,', ',PostalCode,', ',City,', ',Country) AS Address
FROM Customers;

syntax_highlighting.text:
SELECT CustomerName, CONCAT(Address,', ',PostalCode,', ',City,', ',Country) AS Address
FROM Customers;

content.code_html:
SELECT CustomerName, CONCAT(Address,', ',PostalCode,', ',City,', ',Country) AS Address
FROM Customers;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT CustomerName, CONCAT(Address,', ',PostalCode,', ',City,', ',Country) AS Address
FROM Customers;

content.text: Note: To get the SQL statement above to work in Oracle use the following:
content.html: Note: To get the SQL statement above to work in Oracle use the following:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT CustomerName, (Address || ', ' || PostalCode || ' ' || City || ', ' || 
  Country) AS AddressFROM Customers;

content.code:
SELECT CustomerName, (Address || ', ' || PostalCode || ' ' || City || ', ' ||
Country) AS AddressFROM Customers;

syntax_highlighting.text:
SELECT CustomerName, (Address || ', ' || PostalCode || ' ' || City || ', ' || 
  Country) AS AddressFROM Customers;

content.code_html:
SELECT CustomerName, (Address || ', ' || PostalCode || ' ' || City || ', ' || Country) AS Address
FROM Customers;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT CustomerName, (Address || ', ' || PostalCode || ' ' || City || ', ' || 
  Country) AS AddressFROM Customers;

content.text: Alias for Tables
The same rules applies when you want to use an alias for a table.
content.html: The same rules applies when you want to use an alias for a table.

content.code_html: SELECT * FROM Customers AS Persons;

content.text: It might seem useless to use aliases on tables, but when you are using more than one table in your queries, it can make the SQL statements shorter.
content.html: It might seem useless to use aliases on tables, but when you are using more than one table in your queries, it can make the SQL statements shorter.

content.text: The following SQL statement selects all the orders from the customer with CustomerID=4 (Around the Horn). We use the "Customers" and "Orders" tables, and give them the table aliases of "c" and "o" respectively (Here we use aliases to make the SQL shorter):
content.html: The following SQL statement selects all the orders from the customer with CustomerID=4 (Around the Horn). We use the "Customers" and "Orders" tables, and give them the table aliases of "c" and "o" respectively (Here we use aliases to make the SQL shorter):

syntaxHighlighting.text: SELECT o.OrderID, o.OrderDate, c.CustomerNameFROM Customers AS c, Orders AS oWHERE c.CustomerName='Around the Horn' AND c.CustomerID=o.CustomerID;

content.code: SELECT o.OrderID, o.OrderDate, c.CustomerNameFROM Customers AS c, Orders AS oWHERE c.CustomerName='Around the Horn' AND c.CustomerID=o.CustomerID;

syntax_highlighting.text: SELECT o.OrderID, o.OrderDate, c.CustomerNameFROM Customers AS c, Orders AS oWHERE c.CustomerName='Around the Horn' AND c.CustomerID=o.CustomerID;

content.code_html:
SELECT o.OrderID, o.OrderDate, c.CustomerName
FROM Customers AS c, Orders AS o
WHERE c.CustomerName='Around the Horn' AND c.CustomerID=o.CustomerID;

syntax_highlighting_data.text: SELECT o.OrderID, o.OrderDate, c.CustomerNameFROM Customers AS c, Orders AS oWHERE c.CustomerName='Around the Horn' AND c.CustomerID=o.CustomerID;

content.text: The following SQL statement is the same as above, but without aliases:
content.html: The following SQL statement is the same as above, but without aliases:

syntaxHighlighting.text: SELECT Orders.OrderID, Orders.OrderDate, Customers.CustomerNameFROM Customers, OrdersWHERE Customers.CustomerName='Around the Horn' AND Customers.CustomerID=Orders.CustomerID;

content.code: SELECT Orders.OrderID, Orders.OrderDate, Customers.CustomerNameFROM Customers, OrdersWHERE Customers.CustomerName='Around the Horn' AND Customers.CustomerID=Orders.CustomerID;

syntax_highlighting.text: SELECT Orders.OrderID, Orders.OrderDate, Customers.CustomerNameFROM Customers, OrdersWHERE Customers.CustomerName='Around the Horn' AND Customers.CustomerID=Orders.CustomerID;

content.code_html:
SELECT Orders.OrderID, Orders.OrderDate, Customers.CustomerName
FROM Customers, Orders
WHERE Customers.CustomerName='Around the Horn' AND Customers.CustomerID=Orders.CustomerID;

syntax_highlighting_data.text: SELECT Orders.OrderID, Orders.OrderDate, Customers.CustomerNameFROM Customers, OrdersWHERE Customers.CustomerName='Around the Horn' AND Customers.CustomerID=Orders.CustomerID;

content.text: Aliases can be useful when:
content.html: Aliases can be useful when:

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Which SQL statement creates an alias for the CustomerID column as 'ID'?
content.html: Which SQL statement creates an alias for the CustomerID column as 'ID'?

metadata.question: Which SQL statement creates an alias for the CustomerID column as 'ID'?

options.text: SELECT CustomerID AS ID FROM Customers;
SELECT CustomerID TO ID FROM Customers;

content.question: Which SQL statement creates an alias for the CustomerID column as 'ID'?

options.text: SELECT CustomerID AS ID FROM Customers;
SELECT CustomerID TO ID FROM Customers;
